case_name: Mst. Kharbuja Kuer v. Jangbahadur Rai

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 522 of 1959 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: Civil Appeal No. 522 of 1959.

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from judgment and decree dated December 2, 1957 of Patna High Court in S.A. No. 791 of 1963.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and decree dated December 2, 1957, of the Patna High Court in S. A. No. 791 of 1963.

facts.text: Judgment delivered on April 9, 1962 by SUBBA RAO, J.

anchor.surface_text: 1962. April 9. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by SUBBA RAO, J.-This appeal by ,special leave is preferred against the judgment of a single Judge of the Patna High Court,

facts.text: Plaintiff Mst. Kharbuja Kuer is widow of Rameshwar Rai.

anchor.surface_text: The case of the plaintiff, who is the widow of Rameshwar Rai, is that her husband and Jangbahadur, defendant 1, effected a partition of the family property in or about 1924,

facts.text: Rameshwar Rai and Jangbahadur Rai (defendant 1) effected partition of family property in or about 1924.

anchor.surface_text: effected a partition of the family property in or about 1924, that after the partition he was in exclusive possession of the property that fell to his share, that he died in the year 1930,

facts.text: Rameshwar Rai died in 1930.

anchor.surface_text: that he died in the year 1930, that thereafter she and her mother-in-law companytinued to be in possession of the said property,, that her mother-in-law died in 1938,

facts.text: Plaintiff and mother-in-law Kasida Kuer continued in possession after Rameshwar's death.

anchor.surface_text: that thereafter she and her mother-in-law companytinued to be in possession of the said property,, that her mother-in-law died in 1938, that the first defendant asked her and her mother-in-law to execute a power of attorney in his favour,

facts.text: Mother-in-law Kasida Kuer died in 1938.

anchor.surface_text: that her mother-in-law died in 1938, that the first defendant asked her and her mother-in-law to execute a power of attorney in his favour, that they, being pardha- nashin ladies,

facts.text: Plaintiff and mother-in-law executed document on August 24, 1935 believing it to be power of attorney.

anchor.surface_text: that they, being pardha- nashin ladies, executed a document in his favour on August 24, 1935, believing it to be a power of attorney, that subsequently they came to know that it was a maintenance deed companytaining false recitals to the effect that there was numberseparation and that the property was joint family property.

facts.text: Document was maintenance deed containing false recitals of no separation and joint property.

anchor.surface_text: believing it to be a power of attorney, that subsequently they came to know that it was a maintenance deed companytaining false recitals to the effect that there was numberseparation and that the property was joint family property. They also alleged in the plaint that the, deed in question was never read out to them,

facts.text: Document never read out to plaintiff and mother-in-law; scribe and attesting witnesses partisans of first defendant.

anchor.surface_text: They also alleged in the plaint that the, deed in question was never read out to them, that the scribe and the attesting witnesses were partisans of the first defen- dant. It was also alleged that the document was always in the custody of the first defendant,

facts.text: Document always in custody of first defendant.

anchor.surface_text: defendant. It was also alleged that the document was always in the custody of the first defendant, that the plaintiff and her mother-in-law, till the latter is death, were getting the income from the property as they were getting before the execution of the said document

facts.text: Plaintiff and mother-in-law continued receiving income from property as before execution until mother-in-law's death.

anchor.surface_text: that the plaintiff and her mother-in-law, till the latter is death, were getting the income from the property as they were getting before the execution of the said document and that they came to know of the fraud only in 1355 fasli,

facts.text: Plaintiff discovered fraud in 1355 fasli when first defendant interfered with possession.

anchor.surface_text: and that they came to know of the fraud only in 1355 fasli, when the first defendant began to interfere with the possession and occupation of the property by the plaintiff and disclosed to several people that she had only a right to maintenance and thereafter when she got the document read over to her and discovered the fraud.

facts.text: Suit filed in Court of Munsif, Muzaffarpur for declaration of title and that maintenance deed is fraudulent and not binding.

anchor.surface_text: With those allegations, among others, the plaintiff filed a suit in the Court of the Munsif, Muzaffarpur, for the following reliefs On a companysideration of the aforesaid facts and also on adjudicating the plaintiffs title and the absence of title of the defendants, it may be adjudged by the companyrt that the deed of agreement for maintenance is altogether fraudulent and number binding upon the plaintiff.

facts.text: Defendant denied fraud; alleged deed read and explained, Babu Ramnath Singh (plaintiff's brother) present and signed.

anchor.surface_text: The defendant denied the allegations companytained in the plaint and alleged that the deed of maintenance was read over and explained to the plaintiff and her mother-in-law and that one Babu Ramnath Singh, brother of the plaintiff, was present at the time of the execution and affixed his signature on behalf of the plaintiff.

facts.text: Issue No. 3: Allegation of separation between Rameshwar Rai and defendant No. 1 in Asardh 1334 Fs. (1927) correct?

anchor.surface_text: Issue No. 3-Is the allegation of separation between Rameshwar Rai and defendant No. 1 in the month of Asardh 1334 Fs.  1927  companyrect?

facts.text: Issue No. 4: Document dated 24-8-1935 valid? Read over and executed with full knowledge?

anchor.surface_text: Issue No. 4-Is the document dated 24-8-1935 legal and valid? Was the same read over to the plaintiff and the plaintiff executed it with the full knowledge of the companytents?

facts.text: Munsif found Rameshwar Rai died in state of separation; plaintiff and mother-in-law ignorant pardanashin ladies with confidence in D1; document Ex. C not read or understood; decreed suit.

anchor.surface_text: On a companysideration of the entire evidence., the learned Munsif found on issues 3 and 4 that Rameshwar Rai died in state of separation from Jangbahadur, that the plaintiff and her mother-in-law were ignorant pardhanashin- ladies, that the two ladies had full companyfidence in the 1st defendant, and that the document, Ex. C. was number read over to the plaintiff and she did number execute it after understanding the companytents thereof.

facts.text: Subordinate Judge confirmed Munsif's findings and decree on appeal.

anchor.surface_text: On appeal, the learned Subordinate Judge companysidered the entire evidence over again and accepted the said two findings given by the learned Munsif and companyfirmed the decree.

facts.text: Patna High Court single Judge Imam J. set aside concurrent findings on ground of wrong burden of proof; dismissed suit.

anchor.surface_text: But, on second appeal, Imam, J., set aside the companycurrent findings of the two companyrts mainly on the ground that the companyrts had thrown the burden of proof wrongly on the defendant. ... he dismissed the suit.

facts.text: Plaintiff and mother-in-law were pardanashin illiterate ladies with full confidence in first defendant.

anchor.surface_text: Both the companyrts found that the first defendant, on whom the burden lay, number only did number establish that it was executed by the plaintiff with the knowledge of its companytents, but that even apart from the burden of proof, that they also found that the plaintiff and her mother-in-law put their thumb marks on the document under the impression that it was a power of attorney. The finding is one of fact and was based upon the following relevant facts  1  The plaintiff and her mother-in-law were pardanashin and illiterate women-

facts.text: Supreme Court held burden of proof on defendant to show pardanashin ladies understood document.

anchor.surface_text: The burden of proof shall always rest upon the person who seeks to sustain a transaction entered into with a pardanashin lady to establish that the said document was executed by her after clearly understanding the nature of the transaction.

facts.text: Supreme Court restored decree of lower courts, concurrent findings binding.

anchor.surface_text: For the aforesaid reasons, we find that the learned Judge of the High Court had erroneously interferred with the companycurrent findings of fact arrived at by the first two companyrts.

holdings.text: The burden of proof shall always rest upon the person who seeks to sustain a transaction entered into with a pardanashin lady to establish that the said document was executed by her after clearly understanding the nature of the transaction. It should be established that it was not only her physical act but also her mental act.

anchor.surface_text: The burden of proof shall always rest upon the person who seeks to sustain a transaction entered into with a pardanashin lady to establish that the said document was executed by her after clearly understanding the nature of the transaction.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Restated from Privy Council precedents (Farid-un-Nisa, Kali Baksh, etc.); requires proof of mental comprehension via explanation or circumstances; distinguishes from general fraud.

holdings.text: It is settled law that the High Court has no jurisdiction to entertain a second appeal on the ground of erroneous finding of fact.

holdings.text: The learned Munsif and the learned Subordinate Judge approached the evidence from a correct perspective and gave a concurrent finding that the plaintiff executed the document without understanding its nature; the High Court had no jurisdiction to interfere.

anchor.surface_text: Farid-Un-Nisa v. Mukhtar Ahmad  1 , Lord Sumner traces the origin of the custom and states the principle on which the presumption is based. The learned Lord observed In this it has only given the special development, which Indian social usages make necessary, to the general rules of English law, which protect persons, whose disabilities make them dependent upon or subject them to the influence of others, even though nothing in the nature of deception or coercion may have occurred.

precedents.cited_proposition: Origin of the custom of protection for pardanashin ladies and the principle that it is a special development of English law protecting persons under influence, separate from fraud, duress or undue influence.
precedents.cited_holding: In this it has only given the special development, which Indian social usages make necessary, to the general rules of English law, which protect persons, whose disabilities make them dependent upon or subject them to the influence of others, even though nothing in the nature of deception or coercion may have occurred.

precedents.citation: Geresh Chunder Lahoree v. Mst. Bhuggobutty Debia  1

anchor.surface_text: In Geresh Chunder Lahoree v. Mst. Bhuggobutty Debia  1  the Privy Council held that as regards documents taken from pardanashin women the court has to ascertain that the party executing them had been a free agent and duly informed of what she was about. The reason for the rule is that the ordinary presumption that a person understands the document to which he has affixed his name does not apply in the case of a pardanashin woman.

precedents.case_name: Geresh Chunder Lahoree v. Mst. Bhuggobutty Debia
precedents.cited_proposition: As regards documents taken from pardanashin women the court has to ascertain that the party executing them had been a free agent and duly informed of what she was about; ordinary presumption does not apply.

anchor.surface_text: In Kali Baksh v. Ram Gopal  2 , the Privy Council defined the scope of the burden of a person who seeks to sustain a document to which a pardanashin lady was a party in the following words ,,In the first place, the lady was a parda- nashin lady, and the law throws round her a special cloak of protection. It demands that the burden of proof shall in such a case rest, not with those who attack, but with those who found upon the deed, and the proof must go so far as to show affirmatively and conclusively that the deed was not only executed by, but was explained to, and was really understood by the grantor.

precedents.cited_proposition: Burden of proof rests with those who rely on the deed executed by pardanashin lady to show affirmatively and conclusively that it was explained to and understood by her, and executed by free will.
precedents.cited_holding: the law throws round her a special cloak of protection. It demands that the burden of proof shall in such a case rest, not with those who attack, but with those who found upon the deed, and the proof must go so far as to show affirmatively and conclusively that the deed was not only executed by, but was explained to, and was really understood by the grantor.

anchor.surface_text: In Farid-Un-Nisa v. Mukhtar Ahmad  a  it was stated The mere declaration by the settlor, subsequently made, that she had not understood what she was doing, obviously is not in itself conclusive. It must be a question whether, having regard to the proved personality of the settlor, the nature of the settlement, the circumstances under which it was executed, and the whole history of the parties, it is reasonably established that the deed executed was the free and intelligent act of the settler or not.

precedents.cited_proposition: Mere subsequent declaration by settlor that she did not understand is not conclusive; determine from personality, nature of transaction, circumstances, history whether it was free and intelligent act.
precedents.cited_holding: The mere declaration by the settlor, subsequently made, that she had not understood what she was doing, obviously is not in itself conclusive. It must be a question whether... those relying on the deed have discharged the onus which rests upon them.

anchor.surface_text: The same view was again reiterated by the Judicial Committee, through Sir George Rankin, in Jagadish Chandra v. Debnath  1 . Further citation is unnecessary. The legal position has been very well settled. Shortly it may be stated thus The burden of proof shall always rest upon the person who seeks to sustain a transaction entered into with a pardanashin lady to establish that the said document was executed by her after clearly understanding the nature of the transaction.

precedents.cited_proposition: Reiterated the view that the burden on the person relying on document executed by pardanashin lady can be discharged not only by proof of explanation but by other evidence and circumstances.
